title: 114_hr2386
content: The Act may be cited as the "Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act". Congress enacted the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act in 1971 to recognize and settle the aboriginal claims of Alaska Natives to land they traditionally used. The Act awarded $1 billion and 44 million acres of land to Alaska Natives, establishing Native Corporations to manage the funds and land. Alaska Natives are enrolled in 1 of 13 Regional Corporations, with Village or Urban Corporations receiving cash and surface rights to settlement land. The Act awarded cash and surface rights to settlement land to Village or Urban Corporations. However, southeastern Alaska communities like Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell are not eligible under the Act, despite comprising over 20% of the shareholders of the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska. These communities have been seeking eligibility for over 3 decades. In 1993, Congress directed the Secretary of the... The report published in February 1994 revealed that the communities seeking eligibility to form Village or Urban Corporations in southeastern Alaska are similar to those already eligible under the Act. The report published in February 1994 revealed that communities in southeastern Alaska seeking eligibility under the Act had benefits related to Native Alaskan population, historic land use, advocacy for settlement of claims, and omissions not clearly explained in the legislative history. The Act aims to address the exclusion of Alaska Natives from certain communities from eligibility for cultural and financial benefits under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. It authorizes the formation of Urban Corporations for specific communities and the receipt of settlement land. The Act allows Native residents of certain Alaska Native Villages to form Urban Corporations, without affecting existing entitlement to land. Shareholder eligibility is also addressed. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to enroll individual Natives from specific Native Villages to Urban Corporations, granting them 100 shares of Settlement Common Stock. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to enroll individual Natives from specific Native Villages to Urban Corporations, granting them 100 shares of Settlement Common Stock. Natives inheriting shares from a decedent Native will receive the same number of shares in the Urban Corporation as inherited from the decedent. This does not affect entitlement to land. The subsection does not affect entitlement to land of any Regional Corporation under specific sections. SEC. 5. DISTRIBUTION RIGHTS. Section 7 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1606) is amended to address the distribution of corporate funds and other net income among Native members of specific Native Villages. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to address the distribution of corporate funds among Native members of specific Native Villages without affecting revenue distribution ratios or settlement agreements among Native Corporations. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to include urban corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell. Upon incorporation of the Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, the Secretary will offer 1 township of land (23,040 acres) to each corporation as compensation. Additionally, local areas of historical, cultural, traditional, and economic importance will also be offered as compensation. The Secretary will select land for withdrawal and conveyance to Alaska Natives from the Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell based on commercial, subsistence, and cultural criteria. The land chosen will be contiguous and reasonably compact tracts. The Secretary will select land for withdrawal and conveyance to Alaska Natives from specific villages based on criteria. The selected land will be subject to existing rights and provisions, and the Urban Corporations must accept or reject the offer within a year. Urban Corporations in Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell must accept or reject the Secretary's offer. They need to provide a corporate resolution stating the majority shareholder's decision. If the offer is rejected, the Secretary will revise it in consultation with the Urban Corporation and the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska. The Urban Corporation will then have an additional 180 days to accept or reject the revised offer. The Secretary will withdraw the land, convey the surface estate to the Urban Corporation, and convey the subsurface estate to the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska within 180 days of approval. Additionally, roads, trails, facilities, leases, and appurtenances will be conveyed to Urban Corporations without compensation. The Urban Corporations of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell may establish a settlement trust for promoting health, education, welfare, and preserving Native heritage and culture. Proceeds from the trust shall support elders, minor children, and their descendants.
